newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarian c.bank urges banks to extend credits.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarian c.bank urges banks to extend credits.

text.p: The Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) on Wednesday urged local commercial banks to extend loans to firms to boost the stagnant economy and compensate for low gains from state securities, a commercial banker said.

"The BNB suggested that banks should intensify lending aimed at helping the economy recover, which could also compensate the low yield on state treasuries," Ognian Enchev, chairman of the Association of Commercial Banks, told Reuters.

Speaking after a meeting with the BNB board, Enchev said that many banks still remained cautious and considered lending to the real economy a risk because of a lack of financial discipline and the slow pace of restructuring.
"Since Bulgaria introduced the currency board system, the time for aggressive loan extension is over," Enchev said.

A chain of bad loans and lavish lending in the banking sector was halted last year only when the central bank placed a third of the country's banks under supervision and started bankruptcy proceedings against them.
On Tuesday Bulgaria launched a currency board system designed to restore confidence in its shaky banks and currency.
The IMF-prescribed system requires that levs in circulation be matched by foreign exchange reserves and bans central bank lending to the government and commercial banks.
A domestic credit rating information system, due to be set up by the central bank by year-end, will also help commercial banks' lending policy.
Bank closures and past three-digit interest rates have practically stopped access to credits by companies.
Banks have so far focused on investment in high yielding government treasuries, but recent rate cuts have made these investments less attractive.
The fixed exchange rate of 1,000 levs to the mark in effect since Tuesday will lead to a decline in foreign exchange trade on the local market.
The BNB has advised the banks to maintain liquidity through interest rates and lending policies.
